Vol. XXXIV, No. 22

FOOTBALL BANQUET
HELD AT EMERSON
Mills Elected to Captain Next
Year's Grid Team
DEAN BERRY SPEAKS
Coach Van Orman Praises
Work of Players This
Season
Last Monday evening the annual
football banquet was held at the
Emerson Hotel. This banquet ended the football activities for 1929
and started talk and ideas for the
1930 team.
At the formal meeting, held by
the winners of the varsity letter in
this sport, the captain for next year
was elected. This honor was unanimously given to "Bucky" (Dipper)
Mills, the full-back of this year's
team, who received mention by
every picker of an All-Maryland
football team.
Dave Kaufman Toastmaster

After the business meeting, Dave
Kauffman, toastmaster for the
_evening, called the general meeting
to order. He gave a brief address
and then introduced the first speaker: Henry Iddings, Business Manager and Graduate Manager of
Athletics. Mr. Iddings gave an ideal
talk, short and very efficient, in
which he praised the football men
for their spirit during a gloomy season and the fine coaching of Mr.
Van Orman who built up such raw
material into real players who were
unsuccessful merely because of inferior man power.
Dean Berry was called on next.
In his few words he stated that he
had more respect for a good loser
than a winner of great laurels. He
spoke also of the efforts now under
way to abolish the "black list" and
his idea that really worth while men
are those who mingle studies with
extra-curricula activities and are in
every respect good sports and always gentlemen.
Lyons Gives Brief Talk

"Bobby" Lyons spoke to the
gathering; expressed the deep regret of his inability to be on the
field this year and his hope that if
he is in college next year he will be
able to play on the team.
"Bucky" Mills told the fellows,
next, that he looked forward to a
good season in 1930 and he thanked
the men for putting their trust in
him and assured them that he will
lead them with all his power next
year.
When George Darley spoke he
Expressed the appreciation of every
one in his praise of the coach who
worked so hard during a difficult
year.
The coach closed the meeting
with a few words. He lauded the
players for fighting so gamely
against great odds, mentioning,
above all, Guild's prowess throughout the games.
At the banquet, those who were
at the head table beside the toastmaster and speakers were: Dr.
Aaronson, a loyal Hopkins supporter who is known to Jay Athletes for many years back and will
be known to the Black and Blue
players as long as he is anywhere
near Baltimore and can get to
Homewood to watch the practices
and encourage the teams. Assistant
Coaches Mallonee and McGill, were
also seated there.
Twenty-two of this year's squad
attended the affair. Manager Meeks
and Assistant Manager Heinzerling
conclude the list of those present.
Weitzel Awarded Letter

Weitzel, who through a mistake
at the last Athletic Association
Meeting was overlooked for his
Major letter, was awarded the
honor and took his part in voting
for captain of next year.
(Cont. on page 4 col. 3)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1929

LAST YEAR'S FROSH MORE MANLY
PLANS FORMULATED
BY FENCING CLUB
Twenty prospective fencers
put in their appearance Thursday at an organization meeting of the Fencing Club.
Though plans were formulated in a purely tentative
manner, instruction has been
definitely provided for beginners. Ten members, it is
known, are more polished in
feats of the sword. They, it
was learned, will demonstrate
the finer points of fencing to
the uninitiated.
At the second meeting tomorrow, discussion pertinent
to the acquisition of a faculty
adviser will be undertaken.
The Club contemplates in its
activities to make use of the
foil, saber and spee methods
of duelling.

WINTER CONFERENCE TO
BE HELD IN NEW YORK
Interesting Schedule Has Been
Arranged
N. THOMAS TO SPEAK
Price of Admission to be $1.50
and $2.50
This year the Intercollegiate
Winter Conference is to be held
in New York City from December
26 to 28 at the Union Theological
Seminary, 600 West 122nd Street,
New York City.
The basis of the conference is
"The Textile Industry—Battleground of Social Forces." On
Thursday, December 26, Charlotte
Wilder, Justice Wise, James Dombrowsky and Walter Ludwig will
speak on "Life in the Mills as
College Students Have Experienced
It." At this meeting the personal
experiences of college students as
workers in textiles mills and participants in strikes will be given.
Walter Ludwig, who has himself
led groups of students in industry,
will suggest opportunities for work
during the summer. After the talks
there will be a buffet supper at the
home of Norman Thomas. At 8
P. M. the "Student's Place in Industry" will be discussed by Norman Thomas and Peter Nehem y
representative of the National Intercollegiate Committee. At 9 P. M.
the students of New York University will entertain.
On Friday, December 27, at 9.30
A. M."The Growth of an American
Industry" and "The Development
of a Labor Problem" will be discussed by Dr. Louis Bader, Thomas
McMahon, A. J. Muste and Forrest
Bailey. At 2 P. M. Sara Bernheim
Robert Morss Lovett and Harry
W. Lardler will speak on "Can the
Ills of the Textile Industry Be
Cured?" That night at 7 P. M. the
annual dinner of the League for
Industrial Democracy will be held
at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, New York City. Stuart Chase
and Norman Thomas will speak at
this occasion on "Building the City
of the Future." Mr. Leonard Wallstein will act as chairman.

THAN CLASS OF 1933, IS REPORT
Weeks of prodigious labor having
been completed the bull statistical
report for the entering Class of
1928-29 is complete and the results
have been announced by the Physical Department.
There were 270 entering students
compared with 236 last year. Over
half chose physical training in preferance to R. 0. T. C., while last
year the opposite was the case.
Due to the larger number, the
total weight of this year's freshman
class was larger than last year's, although the average weight was only
about one pound less. The total
weight of the class was 36,034.46
pounds, or 18 tons, a mass of
humanity which, if placed in a new
model Ford, would probably break
a spring.
The heaviest freshman, outclassing his nearest competitor by far, is
Louis H. Armstrong, who tipped the
scales at 242 pounds. The lightest
man of the class is William Torn,
who weighs 85 pounds.
The total age of the class was
4,718 years, which, delving into history, would be about the time plans
for the pyramids were being formulated. The average age is 18. There
are an even dozen students of the
innocent age of 16, close perusal of
the lists not showing any of more
tender age. The oldest freshman is
33. Four entered at the age of 22,
while ten entered at the age of discretion.

Chest expansions varied rather
widely according to whether a
future train caller or a brow beater
husband was being measured. The
maximum was five inches, while the
minimum was one inch.
As a whole the class is not as
strong as last year, the average being 537.74 points, as compared with
571.53 points of last year. Individual strength honors were carried off
by Gustave Tribull, Gustave amassing a total of 751.4 points. In case
the blood pressure should prove of
interest to pre-meds, the average
was 117/69, the units of measurement being unknown:
As a whole, the Class of 1928 has
it over the Class of 1929 in weight,
height, chest expansion, and
strength, the only thing being equal
is the average age.
Whether this shows the decadence of civilization or not remains
to be seen. The above be the resuits; make the most of them.
H. F. M. Jr.

Dr. Latane to Address
Adams Prize Debate
To Occur Jan. 16
Club at 12.20 Today
Dr. Latane will be the speaker at
the meeting of the Bankers and
Finance Club which will be held at
12.30 today in Room B, Levering
Hall. He will speak on the subject
of "American Banking in Latin
America."
Dr. Latane, who is Professor of
American History and Creswell
Lecturer on International Law, is
accounted an authority on Latin
America. The Bankers and Finance
Club consider themselves fortunate
in being able to obtain the services
of Dr. Latane, as a period of illness
has kept him from speaking heretofore.
At the meeting of the club held
last Tuesday, Dr. Marshall was supposed to have been the speaker, but
he was called to Washington by
President Hoover to attend a meeting of economists and legal advisers. However, he sent Birdsell,
one of his students to take his
place. Birdsell gave an interesting
talk on the "Development of Specialized Law Relative to Business."

According to an announcement
from Secretary Yudkin, of the Debating Council, the annual Adams
Prize Debate between teams representing the upper two classes of
the University will take place at the
assembly of January 16, 1930.
The trustees of the University
set aside annually the sum of fifty
dollars for the purchase of books to
be awarded as prizes to the undergraduates who are successful in
the annual public debate between
members of the two higher classes.
These prizes, which were originally
offered by the late Professor Herbert B. Adams, are known as the
Adams prizes. a
Immediately upon the return of
students following the Christmas
holidays, notices will be posted for
the try-outs for these two teams.
It will be noted that any member
of the upper two classes will become
eligible both for the prize of fifty
dollars, and for all future activities
of the Debating Council.

COTILLION CLUB
ADMITTED TO S. A. C.

At a regular meeting of the
Student Activities Council,
held last Friday, at 12,20, the
Council voted to recognize
the Cotillion Club as a member of the Council. The members of the Club, who have
done a sufficient amount of
work to warrant their getting
some kind of recognition for
their services, will be awarded Varsity Seals on a consenting vote of the Student
Activities Council. The representation of the Club will
be limited to one member.

JAY QUINT LOSES
OPENER TO TEMPLE
Seigel is High Point Scorer for
Black and Blue Team . .
FINAL SCORE 44-19
Hopkins Out-Scores Philadelphian Five in Second Half
Saturday the Johns Hopkins basketball team bowed to Temple University in the opening game of the
Black and Blue schedule.
Getting away to a slow start the
Jays trailed by a score of 44 to 19
at the end of the game.

guests.
After January, however, the day
of weekly dances will be shifted
from Wednesday to Thursday. The
change was effected to permit the
attendance of graduate students who
have classes on the former day.

EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT
Editor-in-Chief
GEORGE GUMP,'30
Managing Editor
ROBERT S. BAIRD, '30

Retiring from the public eye is
difficult after eight weeks in the
editor's chair. It is strange not to
be greeted every Tuesday and Friday with comments of all kinds on
the day's editorial, but at least the
experience has been worth while.
Editors usually have been tied to
their job for a whole year and had
no chance to view their position
from a disinterested point of view.
But now, as an ex-editor who has
retired to his rightful position as a
lowly subordinate, and whose
journalistic impulse has not died
with his retirement, I find many interesting results of this excursion
into untried fields.

On the other hand the radicalism
which was urged by some readers
is not any more justified, though to
lean more in this direction than
toward extreme conservatism is to
err in a progressive, rather than a
retrogressive way. After all, an editorial has very little effect in changing opinions. It may stimulate the
forming of individual views but
does not often change the general
trend of ideas when it opposes
them.
Of all critics the least bearable are
those who find fault when a man
expresses his opinions frankly.
What possible advantage is to be
gained from repressing your honest
beliefs though they are not in accord
with those of the majority? As
long as you actually harm no one,
why avoid expressing a bold statement merely because it is not altogether diplomatic?

Mr. John Van A. MacMurray
yesterday confirmed the report that
he would accept a professorship at
Johns Hopkins University. No
comment has been publicly made by
University authorities as yet concerning the appointment but it is
said that Mr. MacMurray has complied with a request to receive a
professorship in the school of international relations here.
Landed in Seattle

He is especially adapted to this
branch of study due to his experience in the field of diplomacy. The
reported new member of the Hopkins faculty yesterday landed in
Seattle, before which he was in
China, where he held the post of
American Minister to China.
Mr. MacMurray, until his recent
resignation, had been Minister to
China since April, 1925. Before
receiving the commission to China,
he was at the head of the department concerned with Far East affairs. This department was subsidiary to the State Department.

He was accompanied by his wife
and three children. The party will
remain in Baltimore over Christmas
but is expected on the following day
to journey to Washington, where
the President-elect and his party will
be received at the White House.
He was officially welcomed here by
Governpr Ritchie and Brig.-Gen.
Reckord.

Seigel, Fitch Outstanding

The outstanding Hopkins player
was Seigel, right forward, who
counted for ten of the team's nineteen points. Passareu, White and
Feldman each scored three points.
Heinzerling made a single talley
from scrimmage for two points and
Stude, the younger, counted for one
foul goal. Stude, the elder, the only
other Hopkins man to play, made no
score.
For Temple, Fitch, left guard,
scored seventeen points, six field and
five foul goals. He was followed by
Godfrey, first right forward, then
shifted to right guard, who scored
four of each type goal for a total
of twelve points. Reynolds counted
for eight points. O'Brien, three,
Bonner, two, and Pearson two.
Other Temple men who played but
made no score were: Gisley, Cozer,
Weiler, McCullen, Blair and Cooper.
Dance After Game

Likening religion to an extra gallon of gasoline, the Rev. T. Gutherie Speers, Saturday afternoon,
opened the first of a series of Y.
M. C. A. conferences on religion.
Religion, the pastor declared, is
similar to an automobile whose gas
supply , has been exhausted. The
fundamentalist, he continued, upon
perceiving the need would prescribe
solely a belief in the existence of a
nearby filling station. The modernist would be sceptical of both the
nearness and existence of the station, while the Right Thinking
man would simply reach into the
back seat and procure a spare gallon
of gasoline. This, the speaker declared, was starting "with what one
had" and was the true conception
of religion.
"Religion," Speers said, "is natural and normal. It can't be
strange or mysterious, otherwise
none of us would want it. Most of
us are more religious than we
would want to admit. We must use
what we have and what we've got.
Any religion corresponds to an
extra gallon of gas.
"Religion is admiration of something, no matter. what it may be.
Men who give themselves in the
pursuit of truth or admiration are
religious whether they be doctors,
lawyers, missionaries, or scientists.
Anyone who gives himself for
more than himself is religious. If
you give yourself for something
better than yourself, "you've got
some of the real stuff."
The word "surrender," asserted
the speaker, and its connection with
religion is particularly obnoxious
to the college boy. Religion, he said,
was not concerned with "surrender"
so much as it was with "giving"
and "admiration."

There are no more games scheduled to be played by the Hopkins
five before the Christmas holidays.
Immediately following, however, the
passers will play the team of the
American University, which, last
year, was one of the strongest aggregations. The American U. has
many of its last year's squad back,
and are considered very formidable
again this year. When Hopkins
meets them, the Jay Coach hopes to
have his full first line-up in action,
and hopes to have them equipped
with a variety of new court stunts
to be used throughout the game to
keep the opponents guessing.
Players Expect Home Support

This year the Jay quint expects
to draw a great deal of support at
its home games from the Hopkins
men. The squad has new outfits,
consisting of blue sweat pants and
blue hoods, with white letters.
The playing uniform is of blue
also, with white numerals which
makes it easy for the fans to pick
out the individual players. These
new uniforms were supplied with
the hope of interesting the campus
in their team and having the students attend the Baltimore games
in full force. It is a known psychological fact that the backing of
non-players helps a team in its
playing and that attractive uniforms
helps keep up interest in the team's
activities.
This game with the American
University after the holidays is
the first home game of the season
and the basketball men expect a
good backing from the students. It
will be the first time this season
that the campus will have had a
chance to see its team play and
prospects are favorable for a win.

FOOTBALL BANQUET
HELD AT EMERSON
Mills Elected to Captain Next
Year's Grid Team
DEAN BERRY SPEAKS
Coach Van Orman Praises
Work of Players This
Season
Last Monday evening the annual
football banquet was held at the
Emerson Hotel. This banquet ended the football activities for 1929
and started talk and ideas for the
1930 team.
At the formal meeting, held by
the winners of the varsity letter in
this sport, the captain for next year
was elected. This honor was unanimously given to "Bucky" (Dipper)
Mills, the full-back of this year's
team, who received mention by
every picker of an All-Maryland
football team.
Dave Kaufman Toastmaster

After the business meeting, Dave
Kauffman, toastmaster for the
_evening, called the general meeting
to order. He gave a brief address
and then introduced the first speaker: Henry Iddings, Business Manager and Graduate Manager of
Athletics. Mr. Iddings gave an ideal
talk, short and very efficient, in
which he praised the football men
for their spirit during a gloomy season and the fine coaching of Mr.
Van Orman who built up such raw
material into real players who were
unsuccessful merely because of inferior man power.
Dean Berry was called on next.
In his few words he stated that he
had more respect for a good loser
than a winner of great laurels. He
spoke also of the efforts now under
way to abolish the "black list" and
his idea that really worth while men
are those who mingle studies with
extra-curricula activities and are in
every respect good sports and always gentlemen.
Lyons Gives Brief Talk

"Bobby" Lyons spoke to the
gathering; expressed the deep regret of his inability to be on the
field this year and his hope that if
he is in college next year he will be
able to play on the team.
"Bucky" Mills told the fellows,
next, that he looked forward to a
good season in 1930 and he thanked
the men for putting their trust in
him and assured them that he will
lead them with all his power next
year.
When George Darley spoke he
Expressed the appreciation of every
one in his praise of the coach who
worked so hard during a difficult
year.
The coach closed the meeting
with a few words. He lauded the
players for fighting so gamely
against great odds, mentioning,
above all, Guild's prowess throughout the games.
At the banquet, those who were
at the head table beside the toastmaster and speakers were: Dr.
Aaronson, a loyal Hopkins supporter who is known to Jay Athletes for many years back and will
be known to the Black and Blue
players as long as he is anywhere
near Baltimore and can get to
Homewood to watch the practices
and encourage the teams. Assistant
Coaches Mallonee and McGill, were
also seated there.
Twenty-two of this year's squad
attended the affair. Manager Meeks
and Assistant Manager Heinzerling
conclude the list of those present.
Weitzel Awarded Letter

Weitzel, who through a mistake
at the last Athletic Association
Meeting was overlooked for his
Major letter, was awarded the
honor and took his part in voting
for captain of next year.
(Cont. on page 4 col. 3)

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1929

LAST YEAR'S FROSH MORE MANLY
PLANS FORMULATED
BY FENCING CLUB
Twenty prospective fencers
put in their appearance Thursday at an organization meeting of the Fencing Club.
Though plans were formulated in a purely tentative
manner, instruction has been
definitely provided for beginners. Ten members, it is
known, are more polished in
feats of the sword. They, it
was learned, will demonstrate
the finer points of fencing to
the uninitiated.
At the second meeting tomorrow, discussion pertinent
to the acquisition of a faculty
adviser will be undertaken.
The Club contemplates in its
activities to make use of the
foil, saber and spee methods
of duelling.

WINTER CONFERENCE TO
BE HELD IN NEW YORK
Interesting Schedule Has Been
Arranged
N. THOMAS TO SPEAK
Price of Admission to be $1.50
and $2.50
This year the Intercollegiate
Winter Conference is to be held
in New York City from December
26 to 28 at the Union Theological
Seminary, 600 West 122nd Street,
New York City.
The basis of the conference is
"The Textile Industry—Battleground of Social Forces." On
Thursday, December 26, Charlotte
Wilder, Justice Wise, James Dombrowsky and Walter Ludwig will
speak on "Life in the Mills as
College Students Have Experienced
It." At this meeting the personal
experiences of college students as
workers in textiles mills and participants in strikes will be given.
Walter Ludwig, who has himself
led groups of students in industry,
will suggest opportunities for work
during the summer. After the talks
there will be a buffet supper at the
home of Norman Thomas. At 8
P. M. the "Student's Place in Industry" will be discussed by Norman Thomas and Peter Nehem y
representative of the National Intercollegiate Committee. At 9 P. M.
the students of New York University will entertain.
On Friday, December 27, at 9.30
A. M."The Growth of an American
Industry" and "The Development
of a Labor Problem" will be discussed by Dr. Louis Bader, Thomas
McMahon, A. J. Muste and Forrest
Bailey. At 2 P. M. Sara Bernheim
Robert Morss Lovett and Harry
W. Lardler will speak on "Can the
Ills of the Textile Industry Be
Cured?" That night at 7 P. M. the
annual dinner of the League for
Industrial Democracy will be held
at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, New York City. Stuart Chase
and Norman Thomas will speak at
this occasion on "Building the City
of the Future." Mr. Leonard Wallstein will act as chairman.

THAN CLASS OF 1933, IS REPORT
Weeks of prodigious labor having
been completed the bull statistical
report for the entering Class of
1928-29 is complete and the results
have been announced by the Physical Department.
There were 270 entering students
compared with 236 last year. Over
half chose physical training in preferance to R. 0. T. C., while last
year the opposite was the case.
Due to the larger number, the
total weight of this year's freshman
class was larger than last year's, although the average weight was only
about one pound less. The total
weight of the class was 36,034.46
pounds, or 18 tons, a mass of
humanity which, if placed in a new
model Ford, would probably break
a spring.
The heaviest freshman, outclassing his nearest competitor by far, is
Louis H. Armstrong, who tipped the
scales at 242 pounds. The lightest
man of the class is William Torn,
who weighs 85 pounds.
The total age of the class was
4,718 years, which, delving into history, would be about the time plans
for the pyramids were being formulated. The average age is 18. There
are an even dozen students of the
innocent age of 16, close perusal of
the lists not showing any of more
tender age. The oldest freshman is
33. Four entered at the age of 22,
while ten entered at the age of discretion.

Chest expansions varied rather
widely according to whether a
future train caller or a brow beater
husband was being measured. The
maximum was five inches, while the
minimum was one inch.
As a whole the class is not as
strong as last year, the average being 537.74 points, as compared with
571.53 points of last year. Individual strength honors were carried off
by Gustave Tribull, Gustave amassing a total of 751.4 points. In case
the blood pressure should prove of
interest to pre-meds, the average
was 117/69, the units of measurement being unknown:
As a whole, the Class of 1928 has
it over the Class of 1929 in weight,
height, chest expansion, and
strength, the only thing being equal
is the average age.
Whether this shows the decadence of civilization or not remains
to be seen. The above be the resuits; make the most of them.
H. F. M. Jr.

talk on the "Development of Specialized Law Relative to Business."

According to an announcement
from Secretary Yudkin, of the Debating Council, the annual Adams
Prize Debate between teams representing the upper two classes of

assembly of January 16, 1930.
The trustees of the University
set aside annually the sum of fifty
dollars for the purchase of books to

members of the two higher classes.

offered by the late Professor Herbert B. Adams, are known as the

dollars, and for all future activities
of the Debating Council.

ROBERT S. BAIRD, '30

Retiring from the public eye is
difficult after eight weeks in the
editor's chair. It is strange not to
be greeted every Tuesday and Friday with comments of all kinds on
the day's editorial, but at least the
experience has been worth while.
Editors usually have been tied to
their job for a whole year and had
no chance to view their position
from a disinterested point of view.
But now, as an ex-editor who has
retired to his rightful position as a
lowly subordinate, and whose
journalistic impulse has not died
with his retirement, I find many interesting results of this excursion
into untried fields.

On the other hand the radicalism
which was urged by some readers
is not any more justified, though to
lean more in this direction than
toward extreme conservatism is to
err in a progressive, rather than a
retrogressive way. After all, an editorial has very little effect in changing opinions. It may stimulate the
forming of individual views but
does not often change the general
trend of ideas when it opposes
them.
Of all critics the least bearable are
those who find fault when a man
expresses his opinions frankly.
What possible advantage is to be
gained from repressing your honest
beliefs though they are not in accord
with those of the majority? As
long as you actually harm no one,
why avoid expressing a bold statement merely because it is not altogether diplomatic?

Mr. John Van A. MacMurray
yesterday confirmed the report that
he would accept a professorship at
Johns Hopkins University. No
comment has been publicly made by
University authorities as yet concerning the appointment but it is
said that Mr. MacMurray has complied with a request to receive a
professorship in the school of international relations here.
Landed in Seattle

He is especially adapted to this
branch of study due to his experience in the field of diplomacy. The
reported new member of the Hopkins faculty yesterday landed in
Seattle, before which he was in
China, where he held the post of
American Minister to China.
Mr. MacMurray, until his recent
resignation, had been Minister to
China since April, 1925. Before
receiving the commission to China,
he was at the head of the department concerned with Far East affairs. This department was subsidiary to the State Department.

He was accompanied by his wife
and three children. The party will
remain in Baltimore over Christmas
but is expected on the following day
to journey to Washington, where
the President-elect and his party will
be received at the White House.
He was officially welcomed here by
Governpr Ritchie and Brig.-Gen.
Reckord.

Seigel, Fitch Outstanding

The outstanding Hopkins player
was Seigel, right forward, who
counted for ten of the team's nineteen points. Passareu, White and
Feldman each scored three points.
Heinzerling made a single talley
from scrimmage for two points and
Stude, the younger, counted for one
foul goal. Stude, the elder, the only
other Hopkins man to play, made no
score.
For Temple, Fitch, left guard,
scored seventeen points, six field and
five foul goals. He was followed by
Godfrey, first right forward, then
shifted to right guard, who scored
four of each type goal for a total
of twelve points. Reynolds counted
for eight points. O'Brien, three,
Bonner, two, and Pearson two.
Other Temple men who played but
made no score were: Gisley, Cozer,
Weiler, McCullen, Blair and Cooper.
Dance After Game

Likening religion to an extra gallon of gasoline, the Rev. T. Gutherie Speers, Saturday afternoon,
opened the first of a series of Y.
M. C. A. conferences on religion.
Religion, the pastor declared, is
similar to an automobile whose gas
supply , has been exhausted. The
fundamentalist, he continued, upon
perceiving the need would prescribe
solely a belief in the existence of a
nearby filling station. The modernist would be sceptical of both the
nearness and existence of the station, while the Right Thinking
man would simply reach into the
back seat and procure a spare gallon
of gasoline. This, the speaker declared, was starting "with what one
had" and was the true conception
of religion.
"Religion," Speers said, "is natural and normal. It can't be
strange or mysterious, otherwise
none of us would want it. Most of
us are more religious than we
would want to admit. We must use
what we have and what we've got.
Any religion corresponds to an
extra gallon of gas.
"Religion is admiration of something, no matter. what it may be.
Men who give themselves in the
pursuit of truth or admiration are
religious whether they be doctors,
lawyers, missionaries, or scientists.
Anyone who gives himself for
more than himself is religious. If
you give yourself for something
better than yourself, "you've got
some of the real stuff."
The word "surrender," asserted
the speaker, and its connection with
religion is particularly obnoxious
to the college boy. Religion, he said,
was not concerned with "surrender"
so much as it was with "giving"
and "admiration."

After the game, the Hopkins men
who made the trip to Philadelphia,
Heinzerling-, Siegel, Passareu, the
Stude brothers, White, Straughn,
Feldman, and Goldberg, were entertained at a dance which was given
in their honor by one of Temple
University's best sororities, the
Magnet Club. The dance was held
in the University Building and was
considered, by one of the Jay players, a very fine affair. At the end

There are no more games scheduled to be played by the Hopkins
five before the Christmas holidays.
Immediately following, however, the
passers will play the team of the
American University, which, last
year, was one of the strongest aggregations. The American U. has
many of its last year's squad back,
and are considered very formidable
again this year. When Hopkins
meets them, the Jay Coach hopes to
have his full first line-up in action,
and hopes to have them equipped
with a variety of new court stunts
to be used throughout the game to
keep the opponents guessing.
Players Expect Home Support

This year the Jay quint expects
to draw a great deal of support at
its home games from the Hopkins
men. The squad has new outfits,
consisting of blue sweat pants and
blue hoods, with white letters.
The playing uniform is of blue
also, with white numerals which
makes it easy for the fans to pick
out the individual players. These
new uniforms were supplied with
the hope of interesting the campus
in their team and having the students attend the Baltimore games
in full force. It is a known psychological fact that the backing of
non-players helps a team in its
playing and that attractive uniforms
helps keep up interest in the team's
activities.
This game with the American
University after the holidays is
the first home game of the season
and the basketball men expect a
good backing from the students. It
will be the first time this season
that the campus will have had a
chance to see its team play and
prospects are favorable for a win.
